study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) on ovarian reserve by measuring serum anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels in patients with diminished ovarian reserve (DOR).
results_summary: The study found no significant overall change in AMH levels after TKM treatment, but a significant increase was observed in patients aged under 38. The results suggest TKM may benefit younger patients with DOR, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: 22 patients with diminished ovarian reserve (DOR), divided into age groups (<38 and ≥38 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM), including acupuncture and herbal remedies, as a treatment for idiopathic male infertility (oligoasthenozoospermia).
results_summary: Two patients with oligoasthenozoospermia treated with TKM (acupuncture and/or herbal medicine) showed improved sperm count and motility, leading to successful pregnancies and healthy births. The study suggests TKM may be a viable option for male infertility, but larger trials are needed.
population_specificity: Men with idiopathic oligoasthenozoospermia (low sperm count and motility).

study_goal: To explore patients' perceptions, experiences, and motivations for choosing Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) for chronic fatigue.
results_summary: Patients with chronic fatigue reported physical and psychological difficulties and chose TKM due to dissatisfaction with conventional medicine and prior positive experiences. They found TKM practitioners consider fatigue treatable and valued the doctor-patient relationship, perceiving TKM as effective for unmet long-term needs.
population_specificity: 15 patients with chronic fatigue in South Korea (Seoul, Incheon, Daejeon).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify patient demographics, health issues, and types of acupuncture treatments among those visiting a traditional Korean medical hospital.
results_summary: The study found that the 50-59 age group received acupuncture most frequently, with spine conditions like low back and neck pain being the most common musculoskeletal issues. Acupuncture was highly prevalent for diagnosed diseases, but the study's retrospective nature and single-hospital focus limit generalizability.
population_specificity: Inpatients (1,189) and outpatients (10,138) at Chung-Ju Korean hospital from 2010-2012, primarily aged 40-59.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key factors influencing the choice of Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) over conventional medicine in Korea using nationally representative data.
results_summary: The study found that TKM was more likely to be chosen for certain conditions, particularly musculoskeletal disorders (OR 20.579), nervous system diseases (OR 12.054), and circulatory system diseases (OR 5.267), compared to gastrointestinal diseases. Urban residents were 1.441 times more likely to use TKM than rural residents.
population_specificity: Nationally representative sample from Korea (2008-2009 Korea Health Panel data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Traditional Korean Medicine (acupuncture, pharmacopuncture, and herbal remedies) in improving semen quality in a case of idiopathic male infertility.
results_summary: After 3 months of TKM treatment, the patient showed a 13% increase in sperm motility, a 4% increase in normal sperm morphology, and a 2.5-fold increase in total motile sperm count. The study suggests TKM therapies may improve sperm parameters in idiopathic infertile men.
population_specificity: A 35-year-old infertile man diagnosed with asthenoteratozoospermia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a quality control method for Hwangryunhaedok-tang (HHT) and evaluate its antioxidative and antiproliferative effects on LDL oxidation and vascular smooth muscle cells.
results_summary: HHT demonstrated antioxidative activity by reducing LDL oxidation and inhibited vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation, with compound 2 (baicalin) showing significant effects. The HPLC-PDA method established for quality control showed high precision and recovery rates for the five analyzed compounds.
population_specificity: In vitro (LDL oxidation and vascular smooth muscle cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether PMC-12, a Traditional Korean Medicine prescription, improves cognitive deficits and reduces neuroinflammation in an amyloid-β-induced mouse model and LPS-stimulated BV2 microglia.
results_summary: PMC-12 reversed cognitive deficits in Aβ-injected mice, reduced Aβ expression and neuroinflammation, and decreased inflammatory mediators in both in vivo and in vitro models. It also exhibited anti-inflammatory effects via downregulation of MAPK pathways.
population_specificity: Amyloid-β-induced mouse model and LPS-stimulated murine BV2 microglia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the behaviors of Korean oriental medicine and CAM therapy providers treating cancer patients and to provide background knowledge for establishing policies on CAM management and quality control.
results_summary: The study found that 35.6% of providers had experience treating cancer patients, with varying preferences in treatment methods between medicinal professionals and other CAM providers. Side effects were reported in 7.4% of patients, and legal issues in 12.5%, highlighting differing viewpoints on management approaches.
population_specificity: Providers of Korean oriental medicine and CAM therapy in Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and rank the importance of clinical indicators for pattern identification in Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) treatment for stroke.
results_summary: The study identified four highly significant clinical indicators for differentiating stroke patterns, seven nearly useless indicators, and six confounding indicators requiring further study. The significant indicators should be prioritized in clinical practice.
population_specificity: 1,018 stroke patients assessed by 105 TKM doctors from 11 hospitals.
study_duration: Data collected between September 2006 and December 2010 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Traditional Korean Medicine (acupuncture, moxibustion, and herbal treatment) in treating acute and severe abdominal pain in an elderly patient unresponsive to Western treatments.
results_summary: The patient's abdominal pain and related symptoms completely resolved within 3 days after receiving acupuncture, moxibustion, and the herbal drug DaehwangBuja-Tang. The study suggests Traditional Korean Medicine may be effective for such cases.
population_specificity: Elderly patient with acute and severe abdominal pain diagnosed as Yang deficiency of spleen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to observe recent trends in Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) usage in South Korea and compare patterns over several years.
results_summary: The study found that 66.6% of respondents had a positive attitude toward TKM, with 69.3% visiting TKM clinics 1-4 times in the previous year. Most patients sought acupuncture (95.3%), moxibustion (40.1%), cupping (36.0%), or herbal medicines (35.7%), and 56.1% were satisfied with TKM's effectiveness.
population_specificity: South Korean respondents surveyed in 2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify marker components in Leejung-tang (LJT) and evaluate its inhibitory effect on LDL oxidation.
results_summary: The study successfully quantified five marker components in LJT with high precision and demonstrated its inhibitory effect on LDL oxidation, showing dose-dependent reduction in ApoB fragmentation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 for TBARS assay: 165.7 μg/mL; 50% reduction in REM at 127.7 μg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the clinical and laboratory characteristics of children with epilepsy being treated with traditional Korean medicine (TKM) alongside conventional antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) and to survey the use of other nonpharmacologic combination treatments.
results_summary: The study found that children receiving TKM alongside AEDs used more AEDs, had fewer seizure-free patients (59% vs. 73%), and were more likely to use other combination treatments like language, music, and art therapies.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with epilepsy (398 participants) treated at the Pediatric Neurology Clinic of Pusan National University Children's Hospital.
study_duration: Survey conducted from March 1 to July 31, 2011 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the contributions of Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) to modern medicine, particularly in cancer treatment, and explore its multimodal approach to restoring balance in the body.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that TKM offers a safe and affordable approach to cancer treatment through lifestyle modification, herbal prescriptions, acupuncture, and other methods, but its efficacy and mechanisms are not fully reported. The study advocates for integrating traditional wisdom with modern science to improve cancer outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on cancer treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxicity of 280 Korean medicinal plants against human leukemia cells and identify active phytochemicals and their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that 13 plant extracts showed significant cytotoxicity (IC50 < 10 μg/mL), with Sedum middendorffianum and Lycoris radiata being the most active. Hopeaphenol and deoxynarciclasine were identified as the most cytotoxic phytochemicals, affecting genes related to tumor cell response.
population_specificity: Human CCRF-CEM leukemia cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of inpatient Traditional Korean Medicine treatments (acupuncture, herbal medicine, and herbal wet wrap dressings) for severe atopic dermatitis patients.
results_summary: The study found that Traditional Korean Medicine significantly reduced clinical disease severity, with the mean SCORAD score decreasing from 60.63 to 37.37 during hospitalization. Despite the small sample size, the results were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Inpatients with severe atopic dermatitis (SCORAD score ≥ 40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate the Sasang Personality Questionnaire (SPQ) to assess personality based on Sasang typology for personalized medicine research.
results_summary: The 14-item SPQ demonstrated acceptable reliability (internal consistency and test-retest) and validity, correlating with established personality measures and differentiating between Sasang types. The subscales (behavior, emotionality, cognition) explained 55.77% of total variance.
population_specificity: 245 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which JinPi-tang (JPT) and its active ingredient hesperidin (HES) regulate inflammatory reactions in HaCaT cells.
results_summary: JPT and HES inhibited H(2)O(2)-induced interleukin-8 and tumor necrosis factor-α production, mRNA expression, and suppressed nuclear factor-κB activation, IκBα phosphorylation, p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase, and cyclooxygenase-2 activation, suggesting potential benefits for UV radiation-induced inflammatory skin diseases.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (human keratinocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-allergic and anti-inflammatory effects of Insamhodo-tang (IHT) and elucidate its molecular mechanisms in mast cell-mediated allergy inflammation.
results_summary: IHT reduced systemic anaphylactic shock, dermatitis, and ear swelling in mice, and inhibited inflammatory mediators like IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α in human mast cells. The findings suggest IHT has potential as a treatment for allergic inflammation diseases.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and human mast cells (HMC-1, in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects and underlying mechanisms of CGX, a traditional Korean medicine, against Con A-induced liver injury.
results_summary: CGX treatment reduced liver injury markers (ALT, AST), decreased oxidative stress and cytokine levels, and modulated immune cell populations, suggesting hepatoprotective effects via antioxidant and immune-regulatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: Animal model (Con A-induced liver injury in mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HT008-1, a Traditional Korean Medicine prescription, has neuroprotective effects in a rat model of focal cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: HT008-1 (300 mg/kg) reduced brain infarction by 45.7%, improved motor function in behavioral tests, and down-regulated inflammatory markers. The combined formula showed greater efficacy than its individual component herbs.
population_specificity: Focal cerebral ischemia rat model (middle cerebral artery occlusion followed by reperfusion).
effective_dosage: 30, 100, and 300 mg/kg administered orally twice at 0 and 2 hours after ischemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Traditional Korean Medicine ingredients to inhibit proliferation of uterine leiomyomal cells compared to normal myometrial cells.
results_summary: The study found that several fractions of Traditional Korean Medicine ingredients, particularly from Phlomis umbrosa, Spatholobus suberectus, and Curcuma zedoaria, significantly inhibited leiomyomal cell proliferation and altered cell morphology, with some fractions showing selective efficacy against leiomyoma over normal tissue. Immunohistochemical analysis also indicated inhibition of transforming growth factor-beta receptor 2 in treated leiomyomal tissue.
population_specificity: Human uterine normal myometrial and leiomyomal cell cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the modernization of Traditional Korean Medicine, focusing on historical influences, state policies, and its evolving role in healthcare.
results_summary: The study found that Traditional Korean Medicine's modernization was shaped by Western science, nationalism, economic conditions, and perceived effectiveness, particularly in chronic illness treatment. It highlighted its cultural resilience and integration into national healthcare systems despite Westernization pressures.
population_specificity: Historical and modern Korean populations across different political regimes (Taehan Empire, colonial Korea, North Korea, South Korea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects, underlying mechanisms, and genetic associations of Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM), particularly its application in neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights TKM's components, including medicinal treatment, acupuncture, and Sasang constitutional medicine, and notes recent findings on its therapeutic effects, mechanisms, and pharmacogenomic linkages. Clinical and genetic studies suggest TKM's potential in treating neurological diseases when complemented by modern medicine.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurological disorders like stroke, epilepsy, and Parkinson's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Atractylodes macrocephala Koidz (AMK) protein could suppress ovalbumin (OVA)-mediated allergic diarrhea by preferentially stimulating Th1-type immune responses.
results_summary: The AMK protein sample stimulated Th1-type immune responses, suppressed OVA-mediated allergic diarrhea in mice, reduced total and OVA-specific IgE levels, and increased IFN-gamma production.
population_specificity: Mice systematically challenged with OVA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Chung-Sang-Bo-Ha-Tang (CSBHT) on airway inflammation and remodeling in a murine model of chronic asthma.
results_summary: CSBHT was as effective as dexamethasone in reducing airway inflammation and remodeling, including subepithelial fibrosis and goblet cell hyperplasia, and also lowered IL-5 and IFN-gamma levels in splenocyte cultures.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice sensitized to ovalbumin (OVA) and chronically challenged with aerosolized OVA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunological effects of Chung-Yeul-Gue-Soup-Sa-Gan-Tang (CYT) on CD4(+) T cell proliferation and cytokine expression under different Th conditions.
results_summary: CYT increased CD4(+) T cell proliferation upon activation and enhanced IL-2 expression under Th0 conditions. It promoted Th1 lineage development by increasing Th1-specific cytokines (e.g., interferon-gamma) and suppressing Th2-specific cytokines (e.g., IL-4).
population_specificity: Purified murine CD4(+) T cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of So-Cheong-Ryong-Tang (SCRT) on CD4+ T cell activity and its potential to correct Th2 dominance in allergic conditions.
results_summary: SCRT slightly reduced CD69 expression on CD4+ T cells, increased IL-2 and IL2R-alpha mRNA while decreasing IL-4 mRNA, and elevated IFN-gamma expression, suggesting a shift from Th2 to Th1 dominance without broadly suppressing T cell activity.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice splenocytes (CD4+ T cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Soamsan, a traditional anti-cancer treatment in Korean medicine, enhances antigen-specific immune responses in mice.
results_summary: Soamsan enhanced anti-HEL antibody responses and T-cell proliferation, particularly increasing IgG2b, IgG3, and IgM isotypes. It also augmented B and T cell mitogen-induced proliferation in vitro, linked to glycoproteins and endotoxin-like compounds.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice (low-responders to hen egg-white lysozyme).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic relationships between Korean immigrants and hanui (traditional Korean physicians) in the U.S., focusing on role adaptation and clinical practices.
results_summary: The study found that hanui adapt their practices to meet immigrant clients' expectations, incorporating some biomedical techniques while maintaining traditional methods. Clients reported improvements based on holistic criteria, though conflicts arose due to lack of cooperation between hanui and biomedical physicians.
population_specificity: Korean immigrants in the Washington, D.C., area and four hanui practitioners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of specialization in Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) to improve patient outcomes and integrate TKM with Western medicine.
results_summary: The study highlighted that specialized training in TKM enhances treatment precision, patient outcomes, and clinical research quality, drawing parallels from South Korea's specialist physician system. It also emphasized the need for systematic training and regulatory frameworks to manage risks like drug-herb interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on TKM integration in healthcare systems)
interactions: Drug-herb interactions mentioned as a risk factor

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical efficacy and safety of Gwakhyangjeonggi-san (GJS) in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) patients with gastrointestinal symptoms, using a multi-omics approach.
results_summary: GJS did not significantly improve AD symptoms compared to placebo but improved quality of life and gastrointestinal symptoms. It modulated gut microbiome diversity and reduced gut microbiome-derived uremic toxins.
population_specificity: 52 patients with AD, aged 19-60, who also had gastrointestinal symptoms.
effective_dosage: GJS granules thrice daily for 8 weeks (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an informative leaflet about blood stasis (BS) in Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) could improve patient satisfaction, understanding, and trust in TKM treatment for metabolic diseases.
results_summary: The leaflet group showed significantly higher satisfaction scores in all measured aspects compared to the no-leaflet group, with statistically significant improvements in patient understanding, trust, and treatment satisfaction (all P < .0001). The study confirmed the leaflet's clinical effectiveness without temporal influences.
population_specificity: 40 patients (mean age: 62.3 ± 7.8 years) with symptoms persisting for an average of 16.75 ± 9.3 hours daily and a severity rating of 2.53.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate acupoint selection patterns for FGID patients using Traditional Korean Medicine and identify optimal acupoints via machine learning.
results_summary: The study proposed collecting clinical data to analyze acupoint selection and treatment efficacy but did not report specific outcomes as it is a proposed observational study.
population_specificity: Patients with functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs) such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and functional dyspepsia (FD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical studies on bee venom acupuncture (BVA) for treating neck pain, particularly focusing on its effectiveness and application in Korean publications.
results_summary: The study identified 24 trials involving 316 patients, showing BVA improved neck pain across 16 outcome measures, with herniated intervertebral discs of the cervical spine being the most common diagnosis. However, adverse effects were not thoroughly examined.
population_specificity: Patients with neck pain, particularly those with herniated intervertebral discs of the cervical spine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pharmacopuncture (PA) for improving pain symptoms in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and investigate its therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that PA was effective in managing PD-related pain and associated symptoms, with evidence supporting its therapeutic mechanism. Secondary outcomes also showed improvements in pain intensity, location, and related symptoms like depression and anxiety.
population_specificity: Ninety patients with PD-related pain and sixty healthy controls for comparative brain imaging analysis.
effective_dosage: Study treatment provided 2 days per week for 8 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (8 weeks of intervention, 4 weeks follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic mechanism of Gyejibongnyeong-Hwan (GBH) in alleviating shoulder pain caused by blood stasis using metabolomics.
results_summary: GBH significantly reduced shoulder pain and blood stasis scores compared to the wait-list group, with distinct metabolic pattern changes observed in the treatment group. The study suggests GBH regulates metabolic pathways to alleviate shoulder pain.
population_specificity: 40 participants with shoulder pain related to blood stasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the quality of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) for temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs), including those involving Traditional Korean Medicine.
results_summary: The Traditional Korean Medicine guideline was the highest-scoring among those reviewed, earning a mean score of 79.2% across six quality domains, and was one of only three CPGs to meet the 'high' quality threshold. The study highlighted a general lack of quality in CPGs for TMDs, emphasizing the need for more rigorous guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish standardized indices, postures, and methods for pressure algometry during abdominal examination in Traditional Korean Medicine to enable objective assessments.
results_summary: The study identified key indices for standardized pressure algometry, including target location (CV 12), unit of measurement (MPa), pressure area (4 cm²), and pressure rate (0.098 MPa/s), along with patient posture and measurement intervals. These indices were derived from a review of 22 relevant articles and clinical practice.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on methodology rather than a specific patient population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a traditional East Asian medicine home-based healthcare program for people with disabilities, focusing on pain and quality of life improvements.
results_summary: Participants reported significant improvements in overall pain and quality of life, suggesting the program may be effective for integrative management of these outcomes.
population_specificity: Twenty participants with severe limb or brain impairment from a Public Health Center in Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Traditional Korean Medicine (acupuncture and herbal ointments) could serve as an alternative treatment for third-degree burns in patients unwilling to undergo skin graft surgery.
results_summary: The study found that patients treated with Traditional Korean Medicine showed good skin recovery without adverse effects, based on photographic analysis, quantitative indices, and patient narratives.
population_specificity: Four patients with topical third-degree burns who declined skin graft surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pharmacopuncture treatment for lumbar herniated intervertebral disc (LHIVD) through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed that pharmacopuncture significantly improved pain relief and functional status in LHIVD patients compared to control interventions, though study quality was equivocal.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar herniated intervertebral disc (LHIVD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of combining afatinib with HangAmDan-B1 (HAD-B1) in treating patients with EGFR-positive locally advanced or metastatic NSCLC.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results regarding the effects of HAD-B1 are provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with locally advanced or metastatic (Stage IIIA, B, C/IV) NSCLC and EGFR mutations requiring afatinib therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of integrative medicine rehabilitation (IMR), combining Traditional Korean Medicine with usual rehabilitation, for children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study will assess primary and secondary outcomes, including motor function and quality of life, but results are not yet provided in the abstract. The trial is designed to determine if IMR offers clinical benefits over usual rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-6 years diagnosed with cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: Acupuncture three times a week; herbal medicine (Yukgunza-tang and Yukmijihwang-tang extracts) twice daily.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Naesohwajung-tang (NHT) in treating functional dyspepsia (FD) through a randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not provide results, as it is a trial design paper.
population_specificity: 116 participants aged 19-75 diagnosed with FD according to Rome IV criteria at two Korean medicine hospitals.
effective_dosage: NHT or placebo granules three times a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a diagnosis index for metabolic diseases with blood stasis in Traditional Korean Medicine by analyzing clinical data and blood samples.
results_summary: The study collected specific data for diagnosing metabolic diseases with blood stasis, assessing outcomes such as resistin, serum amyloid P component, C-reactive protein, D-dimer, and blood stasis scores, along with other clinical parameters. The findings will provide evidence regarding the effectiveness of the diagnosis index in managing metabolic diseases with blood stasis.
population_specificity: Participants recruited from Dongguk University Ilsan Oriental Hospital who met the inclusion criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chunggan extract (CGX) in treating liver fibrosis in patients with chronic liver disease.
results_summary: CGX significantly reduced liver stiffness measurement (LSM) scores compared to placebo, particularly in subjects not using antiviral agents. No notable adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver disorders and liver stiffness measurement (LSM) scores between 5.5 and 16 kPa.
interactions: Reduced efficacy noted in subjects using concomitant antiviral agents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining HAD-B1 (Traditional Korean Medicine) with afatinib improves disease control rates and reduces toxicity compared to afatinib alone in EGFR-mutated NSCLC patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; it describes the study design and endpoints. The trial is ongoing to evaluate efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: 66 NSCLC patients with EGFR mutations, locally advanced or metastatic.
effective_dosage: HAD-B1 972 mg/day or 1944 mg/day, combined with afatinib 40 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether HT047, an herbal extract of Scutellaria baicalensis and Pueraria lobata, could improve neurologic status, particularly motor function, and determine its safety in acute ischemic stroke patients.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as it is a trial protocol for a phase II study. The outcomes will assess changes in motor function and safety at different dosages over 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients who had an acute ischemic stroke within the past 14 days, with specific motor and stroke severity scores (FMA ≤55, K-NIHSS 4-15).
effective_dosage: High-dose HT047 (750 mg 3 times a day), low-dose HT047 (500 mg 3 times a day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of SOCG (a modified Traditional Korean Medicine prescription) in treating Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and identify the optimal dose.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a Phase II clinical trial to assess SOCG's efficacy using standardized depression and anxiety scales, but specific results are not provided in the abstract. The trial aims to justify a New Drug Application and Phase III trial if successful.
population_specificity: 148 participants with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (four groups likely testing different doses, but exact amounts not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of Sogyeonghwalhyeol-tang, a Korean herbal medicine, for treating work-related chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study is designed to assess the efficacy and safety of Sogyeonghwalhyeol-tang compared to a placebo in a randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: Patients with work-related chronic low back pain visiting Korean medicine rehabilitation centers.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with a 2-week follow-up.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of So-Cheong-Ryong-Tang (SCRT) for treating perennial allergic rhinitis in Korean adults.
results_summary: SCRT improved nasal symptoms and quality of life after 4 weeks, but effects did not persist post-treatment. No significant changes in immune markers or serious adverse events were observed.
population_specificity: Korean adults with perennial allergic rhinitis.
study_duration: 4 weeks of oral administration, with an 8-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a scientific basis for Traditional Korean Medicine's pattern identification in lung cancer patients using a glycoproteomics approach and BCQ assessment.
results_summary: The study proposed using proteomics to differentiate pattern identification types in lung cancer patients, intending to link glycoprotein profiles with TKM classifications for personalized therapy, but results were not yet reported.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients undergoing surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of the Mibyeongbogam mobile application for subhealth management using Traditional Korean Medicine-based strategies in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study assessed awareness of subhealth status as the primary outcome and health-promoting behaviors, quality of life, and TKM-based health questionnaires as secondary outcomes, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 30 to 49 years in the Republic of Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of electroacupuncture therapy compared to sham electroacupuncture for alleviating poststroke shoulder pain in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a rigorous, double-center, randomized, sham-controlled trial to evaluate electroacupuncture's efficacy and safety, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with shoulder pain from two traditional Korean medicine hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects and safety of Korean herbal medicine (MYOMI-14) on semen quality in infertile men with low semen quality.
results_summary: MYOMI-14 significantly improved sperm concentration, progressive motility, and total motile sperm count, but did not affect Fertility Quality of Life or scrotal skin temperature differences. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Infertile men with low semen quality (n=17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of collaborative treatment (KM and WM) compared to sole treatment for patients with low back pain in Korea.
results_summary: The study will provide clinical and economic information about collaborative treatment for low back pain, potentially influencing future policies, but specific efficacy results are not yet detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with low back pain in South Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical- and cost-effectiveness of collaborative traditional Korean medicine (KM) and Western medicine (WM) treatment in patients with dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study design was outlined, but no specific results were provided in the abstract. The study intended to compare sole treatment (WM or KM alone) with collaborative treatment (both WM and KM) in terms of cognitive function and quality of life outcomes.
population_specificity: 180 patients with dementia or mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current status of clinical research on acupuncture in Traditional Korean Medicine for alleviating symptoms in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The review found that acupuncture may alleviate symptoms like lymphedema, neuropathy, and hot flushes in breast cancer survivors, but the evidence is limited due to few high-quality studies, with only one RCT included.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors experiencing symptoms from cancer therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether side-dependent treatments in Traditional Korean Medicine are more effective for stroke patients with left or right hemiparesis by analyzing gait recovery patterns.
results_summary: The study analyzed gait recovery patterns using spatiotemporal, symmetric, and center of pressure parameters but did not report specific efficacy outcomes; it highlighted potential differences in recovery based on the paralyzed side.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with left or right hemiparesis or hemiplegia.
study_duration: Data collected from September 1, 2017, to June 31, 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of Traditional Korean Medicine (specifically acupuncture) in treating functional constipation compared to sham acupuncture.
results_summary: The study found that real acupuncture showed clinically meaningful improvements in spontaneous complete bowel movements and maintained these improvements for 4 weeks post-treatment, particularly in participants with hard stools. Adverse events were minimal and equally distributed between groups.
population_specificity: Participants with functional constipation.
effective_dosage: Twelve acupuncture sessions over 4 weeks (8 fixed points + 4 individualized points).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with a 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of thread embedding acupuncture combined with conventional acupuncture for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a rigorous trial design to assess the effectiveness of thread embedding acupuncture alongside conventional acupuncture, with primary outcomes focusing on pain reduction and secondary measures including quality of life and disability levels. Results are pending, but the study aims to provide evidence for this combined treatment approach.
population_specificity: 38 outpatients with chronic low back pain recruited from 4 traditional Korean Medicine hospitals.
effective_dosage: Thread embedding acupuncture at 10 points once weekly; conventional acupuncture at 14 points twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of electrical moxibustion compared to traditional indirect moxibustion and usual care for treating knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The study will assess changes in pain and functional outcomes using multiple scales (NRS, VAS, K-WOMAC, PGA, EQ-5D-5L), but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract. Safety will be monitored via adverse events.
population_specificity: 138 participants with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions over 6 weeks (2 sessions per week) at 6 acupoints plus up to 2 "ashi" points if needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of moxibustion treatment for cancer-related fatigue in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study design suggests a rigorous evaluation of moxibustion's effects on cancer-related fatigue, comparing it to sham moxibustion and usual care, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Cancer patients experiencing cancer-related fatigue.
effective_dosage: Moxibustion treatment at CV8, CV12, LI4, and ST36 twice a week for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of Samryungbaekchulsan (SRS) and otilonium bromide (OB) in treating diarrhoea-predominant IBS (D-IBS) compared to their placebos.
results_summary: The study assessed the efficacy of SRS and OB using the Subject's Global Assessment of Relief method and symptom severity scales, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 80 patients with diarrhoea-predominant IBS (D-IBS).
effective_dosage: SRS (5 g/pack, three times a day); OB (one capsule three times a day).
study_duration: 8 weeks of treatment, with a 4-week post-treatment follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether adding Traditional Korean Medicine methods (ear and body acupuncture, aromatherapy) to conventional smoking cessation treatments (NRT, counselling) increases smoking cessation rates.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as it describes a pilot trial design and methodology rather than outcomes. The study is pre-results.
population_specificity: Current smokers over 19 years old who communicate in Korean and meet specific smoking criteria (e.g., >10 cigarettes/day, prior cessation failure, or high nicotine dependence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the relationship among natural products, traditional medicines (including Traditional Korean Medicine), and modern medicine, and explore concepts and methodologies for drug discovery.
results_summary: The study summarized the unique characteristics of eight traditional medicine systems, highlighting their contributions to modern medicine, including abundant clinical experience and diverse chemical structures and biological activities. It noted that natural products and traditional medicines have significant potential for drug discovery but only a fraction of plant species have been scientifically researched.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical patterns of stroke identification in Traditional Korean Medicine (TKM) and standardize its diagnostic approach.
results_summary: The study identified four primary pattern identifications (PI) in stroke patients (Qi-Deficiency, Fire-Heat, Dampness-Phlegm, Yin-Deficiency) and found associations between specific symptoms, obesity, and blood lipids with certain PIs. The results support the standardization of TKM stroke diagnosis.
population_specificity: 4912 stroke patients admitted to 15 TKM university hospitals in Korea (2005–2013).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Gamisoyo-San on generalized anxiety disorder, comparing its differently manufactured preparations (individual extract mixture vs. multi-compound extract).
results_summary: Gamisoyo-San did not significantly improve anxiety levels but showed benefits in quality of life and reduction of depressive, obsessive-compulsive, and somatic symptoms. The multi-compound extract was more effective than the individual extract mixture, particularly in patients with Heart blood deficiency pattern.
population_specificity: 147 patients with generalized anxiety disorder, recruited from November 1st, 2009, to December 16th, 2010.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Bunsimgi-eum (BSGE) on symptoms of Hwa-byung, a condition associated with emotional stagnation in Traditional Korean Medicine.
results_summary: The study found that BSGE did not significantly outperform placebo in improving Hwa-byung symptoms, though both groups showed some within-group improvements. No significant differences were observed between the experimental and control groups across multiple evaluation scales.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with Hwa-byung.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether doctors' attire influences patients' perception of empathy and trustworthiness during Traditional Korean Medicine consultations.
results_summary: Patients preferred white coats and traditional dress, associating them with higher competency, trustworthiness, comfort, and empathy. The "Consultation and Relational Empathy (CARE)" score was significantly higher in the "White coat" and "Traditional" groups compared to "Casual" and "Suit" groups.
population_specificity: 143 patients consulting a Traditional Korean Medicine doctor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiallergic effects and mechanisms of M-tang, a Traditional Korean Medicine, on mast cell-mediated allergic reactions.
results_summary: M-tang inhibited systemic anaphylaxis, ear-swelling response, histamine release, passive cutaneous anaphylaxis, and TNF-α production in activated mast cells, suggesting potential as an antiallergic agent.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Chuna (a Traditional Korean Medicine technique) for treating musculoskeletal pain based on Korean literature.
results_summary: Three RCTs showed favorable effects of Chuna for neck pain and low back pain, while three others found no positive effects for temporomandibular joint disorder and neck pain from traffic accidents. The overall evidence for Chuna's effectiveness was deemed unconvincing, requiring further rigorous trials.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal pain, including neck pain (hypolordotic cervical spine and traffic accident-related), low back pain (general and traffic accident-related), and temporomandibular joint disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and safety of Yukmijihwang-tang on xerostomia in the elderly and to clarify if 'Yin-Deficiency' is a major cause of xerostomia.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as it appears to be a protocol for a future clinical trial.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 60-80 years with xerostomia (score >40 on visual analogue scale and unstimulated salivary flow rate <0.3mL/min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of wet-cupping treatment for persistent non-specific low back pain (PNSLBP) in a pilot study.
results_summary: The study found that wet-cupping significantly reduced pain intensity (PPI scores) compared to the waiting-list group, though pain ratings (NRS) and disability (ODQ) did not show significant differences. No adverse events were reported, and acetaminophen use was lower in the wet-cupping group.
population_specificity: 32 participants with PNSLBP for at least 3 months, recruited from a clinical research center in Korea.
effective_dosage: Wet-cupping treatment at two acupuncture points (BL23, BL24, or BL25) 6 times within 2 weeks.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention with follow-up over 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Banha-sasim-tang for treating functional dyspepsia (FD) and assess the correlation between gastric myoelectrical activity and symptom improvement.
results_summary: The study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to measure differences in gastrointestinal symptoms, dyspepsia severity, and quality of life, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 100 FD patients (50 in Banha-sasim-tang group, 50 in placebo group) across two centers.
study_duration: 6 weeks of administration, with 2 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and clinical foundation of using acupuncture alongside medication for treating cold hands, as a precursor to a larger trial.
results_summary: The study was designed as a pilot RCT to assess acupuncture's potential efficacy and safety for cold hands, but no results were reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 14 subjects with cold hands, likely from the Korean population.
effective_dosage: Acupuncture (three sessions per week for three weeks, totaling nine sessions); nifedipine (5 mg once daily) and beraprost (20 mg three times daily) for three weeks.
study_duration: Five weeks (three weeks of intervention, with assessments up to five weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of policies aimed at reducing trans fatty acids (TFAs) in the food supply and their impact on health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that all types of TFA policies led to reductions in TFAs, with bans being the most effective (virtually eliminating TFAs). Modeling studies indicated that TFA bans would reduce heart disease risk, benefit disadvantaged populations the most, and be cost-saving.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on socioeconomically disadvantaged groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of APD668 (a GPR119 agonist) and linagliptin (a DPPIV inhibitor), alone and in combination, on steatohepatitis progression in mice fed a high trans-fat diet.
results_summary: Monotherapy with APD668 or linagliptin reduced ALT, AST, glucose, cholesterol, and epididymal fat mass, with more pronounced effects in combination. The combination also showed synergistic body weight reduction (-19%) and enhanced active GLP-1 levels, though hepatic triglyceride and cholesterol reductions were not significantly additive.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high trans-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of APD668, a GPR119 agonist, on dyslipidemia and hepatic steatosis in mice fed a high trans-fat diet.
results_summary: APD668 ameliorated hepatic endpoints such as plasma ALT, AST, liver weight, and steatosis in mice fed a high trans-fat diet, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for dyslipidemia and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. However, APD668 did not show anti-dyslipidemic activity in tyloxapol-induced hyperlipidemia.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high trans-fat diet and tyloxapol-induced hyperlipidemia model.
interactions: Combined administration of APD668 and linagliptin increased plasma active GLP-1 levels and improved fat tolerance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess intervention options for reducing trans fat intake in low-income consumers in India through a systems analysis of the food chain.
results_summary: The study found high levels of trans fat in street foods and snacks, with significant household consumption exceeding WHO recommendations, particularly in urban slums. Manufacturers identified challenges in using healthier oils, suggesting a need for multisectoral interventions.
population_specificity: Low-income consumers in rural villages (n = 260) and an urban slum (n = 261) in India, along with vanaspati manufacturers (n = 13) and local food vendors (n = 44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic trans-fat supplementation across two generations of rats alters neuronal membranes, influences mania-like behaviors, and affects lithium's neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: Trans-fat (HVF) supplementation increased amphetamine-induced locomotion and oxidative stress (higher protein carbonyl levels) in rats, while lithium co-treatment normalized these effects. Trans-fat incorporation in the hippocampus was observed, suggesting potential neuropsychiatric implications.
population_specificity: Two generations of female rats and their male offspring.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary supplementation with hydrogenated vegetable fat).
interactions: Lithium co-treatment mitigated trans-fat-related behavioral and oxidative effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of trans fat consumption on behavioral, biochemical, and molecular changes in the brain-cortex of second-generation rats exposed to a mania model.
results_summary: Trans fat (HVF) consumption led to increased hyperactivity, oxidative damage, and molecular changes in the brain-cortex, while fish oil (FO) showed protective effects. HVF incorporation facilitated hyperactive behavior and higher oxidative stress, potentially increasing susceptibility to neuropsychiatric conditions.
population_specificity: Second-generation female rats and their male offspring.
effective_dosage: Not specified for trans fat; amphetamine dosage was 4 mg/kg intraperitoneally once daily for 14 days.
study_duration: From pregnancy and lactation through adulthood (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how trans fat (HVF) consumption over two generations affects hippocampal function, memory, and mania-like behavior in rats compared to other fatty acids.
results_summary: HVF increased reactive species and protein carbonyl levels, reduced catalase activity and dopamine transporter levels, impaired memory, and decreased BDNF mRNA expression, indicating detrimental effects on hippocampal function and behavior.
population_specificity: Two sequential generations of female rats, supplemented from pregnancy through lactation and assessed in adulthood.
study_duration: Supplementation from pregnancy through lactation, with assessments in adulthood.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between trans fat intake and LDL particle number (LDL-P) over a 1-year period in individuals participating in a lifestyle intervention trial.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive correlation between dietary trans fat intake and LDL-P at baseline. A reduction in trans fat intake over 1-year was associated with a reduction in LDL-P, independent of potential confounders.
population_specificity: Family members (N = 400, 33% male, mean age 48 ± 13) of patients hospitalized with cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various policies (e.g., bans, labeling, voluntary limits) in reducing industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFAs) in food.
results_summary: Policies restricting TFAs were associated with significant reductions in TFA levels in food, diets, blood, or breast milk, without increasing total fat content. National and local bans were most effective, while labeling and voluntary limits had varying success depending on food category.
population_specificity: General population (food supply and dietary intake)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary Trans-fat and high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) on hepatic gene expression and liver disease progression using a feline model.
results_summary: The study found that Trans-fat and HFCS exposure promoted hepatic fibrosis and markers of liver dysfunction, along with increased expression of genes related to lipolysis, glycolysis, liver damage/regeneration, and fibrosis.
population_specificity: Domestic cats (feline model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biological effects of industrial trans-fatty acids (TFA) versus natural TFA from ruminant sources on cardiovascular risk factors, inflammation, and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Industrial TFA (elaidic acid) showed detrimental effects on CVD risk factors and potential links to insulin sensitivity and type 2 diabetes, though intervention studies were inconclusive. Natural TFA (vaccenic acid) from dairy and ruminant meat had limited available data on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the adverse health effects of trans fat consumption and the importance of early dietary intervention to promote healthier food choices.
results_summary: The study linked trans fat consumption to negative changes in lipoproteins, systemic inflammation, coronary heart disease, and diabetes mellitus, with evidence of these effects also found in children. It emphasized the need for educational interventions to reduce trans fat intake.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of children and parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cis-9, trans-11 CLA on blood pressure compared to oleic acid and industrial trans fatty acids in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of cis-9, trans-11 CLA on blood pressure compared to oleic acid, with minimal changes in systolic and diastolic BP. Industrial trans fatty acids also showed negligible effects on BP.
population_specificity: 61 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 7% of energy (18.9 g in a diet of 10 MJ/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of restricting artificial trans fat in restaurant foods on public health, particularly in reducing cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found that restricting artificial trans fat in New York City restaurants reduced its use from 50% to less than 2%, leading to more healthful fatty acid profiles in foods and a significant decrease in total saturated fat plus trans fat in products like French fries.
population_specificity: Restaurants in New York City and broader jurisdictions adopting similar laws.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary trans-fatty acids (TFA) on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and how monosodium glutamate (MSG) exacerbates these effects in an animal model.
results_summary: Trans-fat feeding increased serum lipids, hepatic lipogenesis, and macrosteatosis, while MSG caused microsteatosis and elevated oxidative gene expression. Combined TFA+MSG treatment worsened inflammation, lipid storage, and WAT deposition, further reducing Ppargc1a levels.
population_specificity: Animal model (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dairy-derived and industrial trans fatty acids (TFAs) on insulin sensitivity in overweight women.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in fasting glycemia, insulinemia, or insulin sensitivity after four weeks of consuming either dairy- or industrial-source TFAs at nutritional levels. The results suggest that short-term TFA consumption does not impair peripheral insulin sensitivity in insulin-resistant women.
population_specificity: Overweight women with abdominal obesity (waist circumference >88 cm and BMI >28 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 0.54 g/d (low-TFA lipids), 4.86 g/d (ruminant TFA-rich lipids), or 5.58 g/d (industrial TFA-rich lipids).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate research hotspots and trends in TMS-based depression treatment using bibliometric analysis.
results_summary: The study identified 702 articles, with clinical studies predominating, and highlighted theta burst stimulation (TBS), functional connectivity, and frequency as recent research hotspots. TMS, particularly TBS, was found to enhance therapeutic efficacy and patient experience, with neuroimaging integration representing a promising direction.
population_specificity: Patients with treatment-resistant depression (implied by clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of industrially produced trans fatty acids (IP-TFA) intake on biomarkers of inflammation, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction in healthy overweight postmenopausal women.
results_summary: IP-TFA intake increased serum TNFα and plasma soluble TNF receptors, indicating activation of the TNFα system, but did not affect other biomarkers like C-reactive protein, IL6, or adiponectin. The study suggests IP-TFA may contribute to cardiovascular disease through TNFα system activation.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight postmenopausal women (52 participants, 49 completers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare adverse effect (severe bradycardia) associated with rTMS in a patient with MDD and PVCs.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS triggered severe bradycardia in a patient with pre-existing PVCs, which resolved upon pausing treatment and recurred upon resumption, suggesting a potential ANS-mediated effect.
population_specificity: A 46-year-old Chinese woman with a 7-year history of MDD and 6-year history of PVCs.
interactions: Concurrent use of paroxetine, tandospirone citrate, and metoprolol (later discontinued).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in improving motor function in patients with spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found statistically significant improvements in motor function, with SARA scores showing a mean difference of -1.56 and ICARS scores improving by -3.16 compared to sham. Low-frequency and intermittent theta burst stimulation protocols were particularly effective.
population_specificity: Hereditary spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (subgroup analyses included low-frequency, high-frequency, and intermittent theta burst stimulation protocols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of adjunctive deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) in reducing obsessive-compulsive, anxiety, and depressive symptoms in patients with treatment-resistant obsessive-compulsive disorder.
results_summary: Active dTMS significantly reduced Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) scores compared to sham, with a large effect size (1.39) and high response rates (75% vs. 5%). Anxiety and depressive symptoms also improved significantly in the active group.
population_specificity: Forty-nine obsessive-compulsive disorder patients with inadequate response to standard treatments.
effective_dosage: High-frequency dTMS (20 Hz) administered in 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) for subjective chronic tinnitus through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: rTMS showed short-term efficacy (1 month) in improving tinnitus symptoms (THI and VAS scores) but no significant long-term effects (6 months) or immediate impact on TQ and LM scores. The analysis concluded that while rTMS has some efficacy, more robust RCTs are needed to validate its effectiveness.
population_specificity: 1,105 chronic tinnitus patients across 16 randomized controlled trials.
study_duration: Short-term (1 month) and long-term (6 months) follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential, safety, and clinical applications of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS), particularly in treatment-resistant depression (TRD), and discuss innovations like theta burst stimulation and accelerated scheduling.
results_summary: The study found that TMS has substantial clinical trial-derived evidence supporting its antidepressant efficacy, with several protocols and devices receiving FDA clearance for TRD and other neuropsychiatric disorders. Innovations such as theta burst stimulation and accelerated scheduling are increasingly applied in clinical practice.
population_specificity: Primarily patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) and other neuropsychiatric disorders like obsessive-compulsive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) could alleviate static and kinetic disequilibrium in patients with myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME).
results_summary: rTMS treatment effectively alleviated both static and kinetic disequilibrium in 85% of treated patients, suggesting a central vestibular origin for these symptoms. The study also found a high prevalence of disequilibrium in ME patients, linked to orthostatic intolerance and gait disturbance.
population_specificity: 160 ME patients (53 males, 107 females) with a mean age of 37 ± 12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-frequency rTMS could effectively reduce body weight in obese patients with chronic stable schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in weight and BMI in the active rTMS group compared to sham, along with improvements in cognitive functions like memory and attention. Weight and BMI changes were correlated with cognitive improvements.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) with chronic stable schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether SARM1 and its related mechanisms are involved in the neuroprotective effects of TMS on cognitive function after cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: TMS significantly reduced levels of SARM1, NF-κB, and Bax while increasing levels of HSP70, Bcl-2, GAP-43, NF-200, BDNF, and MBP, leading to reduced hippocampal cell apoptosis and improved spatial learning and memory in rats. Overexpression of SARM1 reversed these neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Middle cerebral artery occlusion/reperfusion (MCAO/R) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rTMS combined with bipolar depression triple therapy is more effective and safer than triple therapy alone or with sham stimulation in reducing non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI) among female adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS combined with bipolar depression triple therapy significantly reduced HAMA, HAMD, and NGASR scores compared to triple therapy alone or with sham stimulation, indicating a definite effect on reducing NSSI in female adolescents.
population_specificity: 45 female adolescent patients with NSSI from two hospitals in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of treatment response to rTMS in patients with treatment-resistant depression using machine learning techniques.
results_summary: The study found that machine learning models could reasonably predict response and remission to rTMS, with certain clinical factors (e.g., comorbid anxiety, obesity, medication use) negatively impacting outcomes, while others (e.g., trauma history, former tobacco use) improved response. Intermittent theta burst stimulation and more rTMS sessions were associated with better outcomes.
population_specificity: 232 patients with treatment-resistant depression (mean age 54.5, 63.4% women) treated at the University of California, San Diego Interventional Psychiatry Program.
interactions: Concurrent benzodiazepine or antipsychotic use was associated with reduced likelihood of response or remission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of rTMS on cognition in stroke survivors, identify potential beneficiaries, define optimal therapeutic parameters, and provide recommendations.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a small, non-significant effect of rTMS on global cognitive function in stroke survivors, with high heterogeneity and substantial variability in outcomes. Some studies reported improvements in specific cognitive domains, but overall evidence was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (mean age 60.17 years, n=608)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) versus 10 Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on swallowing function, serum indexes, and functional fMRI in patients with post-stroke dysphagia (PSD).
results_summary: The study describes the design of a randomized controlled trial but does not report final results. It plans to evaluate swallowing function, serum indexes, and fMRI changes at multiple time points during and after treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke dysphagia (PSD).
effective_dosage: iTBS group: three 50 Hz pulses, repeated at 5 Hz, 100% intensity threshold, 600 pulses/time; rTMS group: 10 Hz pulse, 100% intensity threshold, 1000 pulses/time. Administered once daily, 5 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore patients' experiences with TMS, factors influencing their treatment choices, and comparative views on its acceptability relative to pharmacological interventions in private healthcare settings.
results_summary: Participants reported predominantly positive perceptions of TMS, citing improvements in mood, anxiety reduction, and enhanced daily functioning. Barriers such as high treatment costs and limited insurance coverage were noted as significant deterrents.
population_specificity: 20 patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) or adjustment disorder (AD) in Romanian private practices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal frequency (1 Hz vs. 10 Hz) of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) for reducing suicidal ideation in adolescents with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: Both 1 Hz and 10 Hz TMS significantly reduced suicidal ideation over six weeks, but the effect was attenuated and rendered non-significant after adjusting for changes in depression severity. No significant difference was found between the two frequencies, suggesting low-frequency TMS may be as effective as high-frequency TMS.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-18 years with major depressive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rTMS in older versus younger patients with treatment-resistant depression and determine if age affects clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Both age groups showed significant improvement in depressive symptoms, with older adults having higher remission rates at end-of-treatment (though not at follow-up). Female sex was the only significant predictor of remission at follow-up.
population_specificity: 272 patients with treatment-resistant depression (older ≥60 years, younger <60 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether there are sex-specific differences in the effectiveness of rTMS treatment for depressive disorders.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in treatment outcomes between female and male patients, with similar response and remission rates. An exploratory analysis suggested a slight tendency for better outcomes in females with the 20 Hz protocol.
population_specificity: 984 depressive patients (539 females, 445 males)
effective_dosage: Various protocols, including 10 Hz, 20 Hz, Theta burst, and accelerated protocols over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 1 Hz rTMS targeting the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex could improve cognitive flexibility and sleep quality in undergraduates with insomnia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS significantly improved sleep quality (reduced ISI and PSQI scores) and enhanced cognitive flexibility (increased CFI scores, reduced switch costs in the N-L task, and altered ERP amplitudes and beta-band ERD) compared to sham stimulation.
population_specificity: Undergraduates with insomnia symptoms (n=29, split into Active and Sham groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers and facilitators to accessing rTMS for peripartum depression (PPD) and assess awareness and willingness to use rTMS among patients and providers.
results_summary: The study found that 83% of participants were unaware of rTMS, but 75% were willing to receive or refer to rTMS after a brief description. Key barriers included systemic challenges, stigma, and access issues, while facilitators included mom-centered care and mental health education.
population_specificity: Individuals who experienced depressive symptoms during the peripartum period and health providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of rTMS in improving brain function and clinical symptoms in chronic insomnia patients, using fNIRS as a screening tool.
results_summary: rTMS treatment significantly increased activation in relevant brain regions and alleviated symptoms in chronic insomnia patients, as evidenced by improved PSQI, SAS, and SDS scores. fNIRS showed weaker PFC responses in CI patients compared to healthy controls, which improved post-treatment.
population_specificity: 30 chronic insomnia patients and 30 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 1 Hz rTMS targeting the right DLPFC.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of rTMS combined with pharmacological interventions on sleep quality and depressive symptoms in depressed patients, identify optimal stimulation parameters, and explore clinical applications for personalized therapy.
results_summary: rTMS significantly improved sleep quality and reduced depressive symptoms, with optimal parameters including high-frequency stimulation targeting the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. However, rTMS alone may be insufficient for patients with prolonged disease course or severe symptoms, suggesting the need for additional therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with depression, including those with vascular and other neurological comorbidities.
effective_dosage: High-frequency rTMS, high stimulation intensity, low total pulse count (<1200 pulses), session duration ≤20 min daily for sleep quality; 21-30 min daily for depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rTMS improves depressive symptoms, cognitive function, and BDNF levels in TRD patients, and whether baseline BDNF or lifetime suicidal attempts influence outcomes.
results_summary: rTMS significantly reduced depressive symptoms and modestly improved cognitive performance (MMSE and Digit Span), but did not significantly alter BDNF levels. Baseline BDNF and lifetime suicidal attempts did not predict or moderate outcomes.
population_specificity: 25 patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of rTMS over four weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical research status of rTMS combined with obligatory motor therapy for post-stroke sensorimotor recovery.
results_summary: The abstract highlights rTMS as a promising non-invasive neuromodulation technique for enhancing functional recovery post-stroke, particularly when combined with constraint-induced movement therapy (CIMT), though practical application issues remain.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with long-term sensorimotor impairment, particularly affecting upper limb mobility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and transcranial photobiomodulation (tPBM) on working memory in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) patients.
results_summary: The combined TMS and tPBM intervention significantly improved working memory capacity compared to monostimulation and sham stimulation, with enhanced functional connectivity and increased wavelet amplitude in task-relevant cortical regions.
population_specificity: 88 participants with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore determinants of speech-language pathologists' behavior influencing the translation of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) into clinical practice and examine these within broader profession-wide research-to-practice gaps.
results_summary: The study identified four key behavioral determinants affecting TMS translation: actual knowledge/experience, perceptions of professional role, mindset/emotions, and environmental factors. It also provided a taxonomy of nine recommendations to bridge technology translation gaps in speech-language pathology.
population_specificity: 10 speech-language pathologists categorized by TMS knowledge/experience levels (novice, intermediate, expert).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of cerebellar transcranial magnetic stimulation (cTMS) for improving motor dysfunction in stroke patients and explore the effects of disease stage, stimulation modes, intensity, and treatment duration.
results_summary: cTMS significantly improved motor function in stroke patients, particularly during the subacute phase, with notable enhancements in balance, gait, and muscle coordination. The effects were consistent across different stimulation modes, intensities (≤ 80%RMT), and treatment durations.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with motor dysfunction

study_goal: To examine the efficacy and safety of 1-Hz rTMS to the right prefrontal cortex in patients with treatment-resistant bipolar depression.
results_summary: The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of 1-Hz rTMS for bipolar depression, but results are not yet reported as it is a planned trial. The primary endpoint will be changes in depression scores during the acute treatment period.
population_specificity: Patients with treatment-resistant bipolar depression.
effective_dosage: 1-Hz frequency, 120% motor threshold intensity, 1800 seconds duration, 5 days a week for 4 weeks.
study_duration: 4 weeks (acute treatment period), with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: To evaluate the utility of TMS as an assessment and treatment tool for chronic vestibular disorders and propose recommendations for future research.
results_summary: TMS showed promise as both a neurophysiological assessment tool and a neuromodulatory intervention, with statistically significant improvements in dizziness and postural control, though clinically significant improvements were not observed. Methodological limitations suggest caution in interpreting results.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic vestibular disorders, particularly Mal de Debarquement syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) as a therapeutic intervention for substance use disorders (SUDs) and explore neuroimaging-guided TMS practices.
results_summary: The review found that TMS can reduce cravings and substance use across SUDs, with evidence from randomized clinical trials (RCTs), but highlights the need for standardized protocols. Neuroimaging techniques showed functional connectivity changes, suggesting potential biomarkers for treatment response.
population_specificity: Individuals with substance use disorders (SUDs).
effective_dosage: Not specified (various TMS protocols discussed, including repetitive, deep, single-pulse, paired-pulse, and theta burst stimulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) could reverse mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to normal cognitive function and explore the underlying neural mechanisms.
results_summary: MCI participants who reverted to normal cognition (MCI-R) showed significant improvements in memory after rTMS, while those who did not revert (MCI-M) had more severe cognitive and functional connectivity impairments. Baseline functional connectivity in key brain networks (DMN, ECN, FPN) predicted reversion likelihood.
population_specificity: 25 participants with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and 15 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) in improving motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: High-frequency TMS targeting the primary and supplementary motor cortex showed significant improvements in general motor impairment, gait, functional mobility, and balance with minimal side effects. Optimal effects were associated with higher session numbers, more pulses per session, and the F8 coil type, though further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease
effective_dosage: Not specified (parameters included high-frequency stimulation, higher number of sessions, greater pulses per session, and F8 coil type)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the additive efficacy and feasibility of multilocus rTMS in patients treated for more than one concurrent neurological or psychiatric disorder.
results_summary: The study found an 84% response rate to multilocus rTMS in at least one condition, with 85% of patients reporting a positive Global Impression of Change. The combination of pain and depression was the most frequent comorbidity addressed.
population_specificity: 31 patients (19 women, 12 men, median age 49 years) with combinations of chronic pain, depression, tinnitus, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and eating disorder.
effective_dosage: Protocol and cortical target combinations varied according to indications; a 10-day rTMS trial was conducted (9 days in 2 cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cerebellar repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on stroke rehabilitation, focusing on post-stroke dysphagia and motor dysfunction.
