results_summary: Cerebellar rTMS showed statistically significant improvements in swallowing function (measured by FEDSS, PAS, and SSA) and motor function (measured by BBS and BI) compared to control groups. The technique demonstrated promise in enhancing stroke rehabilitation outcomes.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients (n=638), including those with dysphagia and motor dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether M1 and cerebellar rTMS enhance motor learning in older adults compared to sham stimulation.
results_summary: Both M1 and cerebellar rTMS improved online motor learning compared to sham, with cerebellar rTMS showing greater effectiveness in consolidating motor learning over time. The sham group did not maintain motor learning benefits.
population_specificity: Seventy healthy older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the optimal number of sessions and parameters (frequency, intensity, pulses per session/treatment) of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) for improving post-stroke upper extremity function.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS combined with other therapies significantly improved upper extremity motor function, with optimal results seen with ≥15 sessions, frequencies >1 Hz, intensities <100% of resting motor threshold, ≥1000 pulses per session, and ≥12,000 pulses per treatment.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients with upper extremity dysfunction (897 participants across 35 randomized clinical trials).
effective_dosage: Frequencies >1 Hz, intensities <100% of resting motor threshold, ≥1000 pulses per session, and ≥12,000 pulses per treatment.
study_duration: At least 15 sessions (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits and limitations of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) as a treatment for post-stroke epilepsy (PSE).
results_summary: Initial studies suggest rTMS may reduce seizure burden, with some evidence of fewer seizures within two weeks of treatment. It appears more effective when combined with medication, particularly for patients with frontal/temporal lobe lesions and complex partial seizures. However, current evidence is limited by small sample sizes and methodological variations.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke epilepsy (PSE).
interactions: More effective when used in combination with medication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether rTMS over the cerebellum enhances the effects of inhibitory rTMS for motor recovery in subacute ischemic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS over the cerebellum significantly improved upper extremity motor function in subacute stroke patients compared to sham stimulation, with effects persisting at 2-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute ischemic stroke (n=20).
effective_dosage: Ten daily sessions of high-frequency rTMS over the contralesional cerebellum for 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of high-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (HF-rTMS) on white matter integrity and neurological recovery after ischemic stroke in a rat model.
results_summary: HF-rTMS significantly reduced infarct size and improved neurological function, as measured by mNSS, while enhancing white matter integrity, evidenced by increased FA values and corroborated by LFB staining and TEM. The treatment showed benefits in multiple white matter tracts, suggesting its role in poststroke recovery.
population_specificity: Rat model of middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different doses of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (1 Hz vs. 10 Hz) affect irritability and depressive symptoms in adolescents with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: Irritability significantly improved alongside overall depression symptoms in both TMS groups (1 Hz and 10 Hz), with early irritability improvements predicting better treatment response. The study suggests irritability is a key correlate of disease severity and treatment response in adolescent MDD.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-18 with a DSM-5 diagnosis of major depressive disorder (N = 41).
effective_dosage: 1 Hz and 10 Hz TMS, administered over 30 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and neurophysiological effectiveness of fMRI-connectivity-guided personalized rTMS for treatment-resistant major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in depression (MADRS) and anxiety (HAM-A) scores post-treatment, with higher response and remission rates in patients without complex comorbidities. Functional brain connectivity in the personalized DLPFC-SGC pathway also showed less anti-correlation post-treatment.
population_specificity: Adults aged 19-84 with treatment-resistant MDD (N=61), including subgroups with bipolar or neurological disorders (N=8) and those qualifying for RCTs (N=19).
effective_dosage: 20 or 30 weekday sessions of DLPFC rTMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the roles and interhemispheric interactions of the bilateral supramarginal gyri (SMGs) in vocal motor control using dual-site continuous theta burst stimulation (c-TBS).
results_summary: Unilateral c-TBS over the SMG reduced vocal compensation and P2 responses, suggesting causal involvement in vocal feedback control, while bilateral c-TBS showed no effect, indicating an interhemispheric balancing mechanism. Source localization revealed distinct but interconnected networks for left and right SMG stimulation.
population_specificity: Participants involved in vocalizing vowel sounds under auditory feedback perturbations (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Continuous theta burst stimulation (c-TBS) protocol (specific parameters not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and functional engagement of the Beam/F3 scalp-based targeting method for TMS in treating depression, using neuroimaging and E-field modeling.
results_summary: The study found that the Beam/F3 method reliably targets the dLPFC and that anticorrelation between the stimulation center and sgACC, as well as E-field magnitude at specific prefrontal peaks, correlated with antidepressant symptom response early and at the end of treatment.
population_specificity: Veterans at four Veterans Affairs hospitals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of dual-target rTMS (10 Hz) in enhancing brain oscillatory activity and functional connectivity in patients with minimally conscious state (MCS).
results_summary: The study found that 10 Hz dual-target rTMS enhanced brain oscillatory activity, reducing delta-band and increasing alpha-band activity in frontal, central, and parietal regions, with improved long-distance coherence (F3-P4) in the alpha-band. No significant changes were observed in the sham group.
population_specificity: 20 patients with minimally conscious state (MCS).
effective_dosage: 10 Hz rTMS targeting left prefrontal and parietal cortices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if rTMS targeting the DLPFC could improve headache impact and mood symptoms in TBI patients with major depression.
results_summary: The PTH-1 group showed significant improvements in depression and anxiety but not in headache impact, though over half reported reduced headache severity and duration. The PTH-2 group, treated at a refined target, exhibited significant reductions in headache impact, anxiety, and depression.
population_specificity: Outpatients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) histories and major depression.
study_duration: 4 weeks for PTH-2 group (1-2 weeks for anxiety/depression improvements)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in improving cognitive and functional outcomes in Alzheimer's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS significantly improved cognitive function, memory, language abilities, and motor performance in AD patients, particularly with high-frequency protocols (20 Hz) targeting key brain regions. These effects were linked to enhanced synaptic plasticity, neurotrophic factor expression, and reduced pathological protein aggregation, with benefits potentially lasting months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Alzheimer's disease patients
effective_dosage: High-frequency protocols (20 Hz), minimum of 20 sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in cerebral hemodynamics before and after rTMS treatment in patients with depression, assessing its impact based on symptom severity.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS treatment significantly increased hemodynamic response in the frontopolar cortex and left lateral frontal regions, correlating with improvements in depressive symptoms. Patients with higher baseline severity showed reduced blood flow pre-treatment, which improved post-treatment, suggesting rTMS may promote neuroplasticity in specific brain regions.
population_specificity: 45 patients with depression, classified by severity using the HAM-D 17 scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) as a treatment for adolescent depression, complementing or providing an alternative to psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that TMS has demonstrated efficacy and safety in treating depression in adolescents, leading to FDA approval for ages 15 to 17. Insurance coverage is increasing, making TMS more accessible to patients.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 15 to 17 years with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) as a cognitive enhancement strategy in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and assess its effects on working memory, new learning, and executive function.
results_summary: The study is a pilot trial to collect preliminary data on iTBS effects in MCI, with exploratory objectives to evaluate fMRI, HD-EEG, and sleep architecture as potential biomarkers. Results are not yet reported, but the study design suggests potential cognitive benefits.
population_specificity: 20 participants with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 10 days of active iTBS (left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex or left lateral parietal cortex) or control (vertex), totaling 20 sessions per participant.
study_duration: 10 days per treatment arm, with a 4-6 week washout period between cross-over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the racial and ethnic makeup of patients treated with TMS for treatment-resistant depression and assess associations between demographic factors and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Roughly half of the 71 patients responded to TMS, and a third achieved remission. Racial minorities were underrepresented (9% of the sample), but all responded to treatment. No significant associations were found between age, insurance status, and treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with treatment-resistant depression at an urban, Midwestern academic center.
study_duration: From July 2018 to February 2024 (retrospective chart review period)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of TMS targeting the left DLPFC in improving dizziness and mood disorders in patients with PPPD.
results_summary: TMS significantly reduced dizziness and anxiety levels compared to baseline and sham treatment, with effects sustained at 3 months. Depression scores also improved in the TMS group at 2 weeks and 1 month, while the sham group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 66 patients with PPPD (median age 54.5 years, 63.6% women) from a hospital in China.
effective_dosage: 10 Hz, 20 min per session, 10 sessions over 2 weeks.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 1 and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on focal refractory epilepsy in a patient with persistent epileptiform discharges.
results_summary: tDCS significantly decreased EEG spike frequency initially, but the patient's condition worsened after 2 weeks. rTMS treatment resulted in an increase in spike frequency and worsened symptoms.
population_specificity: A 20-year-old female with persistent epileptiform discharges in the left occipital region consistent with focal status epilepticus.
effective_dosage: rTMS (1 Hz, 1800 pulses) for five consecutive days.
study_duration: Five consecutive days for both tDCS and rTMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and continuous effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) on local and distributed brain activities.
results_summary: DLPFC-rTMS induced immediate cortical excitability in frontal regions and continuous effects in the parietal cortex for up to 60 minutes, with these patterns reliably identified across TMS-induced field potentials and oscillations.
population_specificity: 24 participants in a double-blinded, sham-controlled study.
study_duration: Single-session stimulation with measurements at baseline, 5 minutes, and 60 minutes post-stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) as a treatment for refractory and superrefractory status epilepticus (RSE/SRSE).
results_summary: rTMS caused cessation of (S)RSE in 75.8% of patients within four days, though recurrence occurred in 47% of cases with follow-up data. Three deaths were reported but attributed to underlying disease, not rTMS.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory or superrefractory status epilepticus (33 total, including 17 with epilepsia partialis continua and 7 with new-onset RSE).
study_duration: Median duration of (S)RSE before rTMS was 70 days (range: 2-7300 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-frequency rTMS on glioblastoma (GBM) models and elucidate its underlying biological mechanisms.
results_summary: Low-frequency rTMS significantly inhibited GBM cell proliferation, suppressed EGFR and EphA2 activation, inhibited key signaling pathways (ERK/JNK/p38 and PI3K/AKT/mTOR), induced apoptosis, and downregulated MMP2/MMP9 expression, reducing tumor invasion. In vivo, rTMS suppressed GBM progression by downregulating FLNA and FLNC expression.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo glioblastoma (GBM) models.
study_duration: Daily treatment duration not specified beyond "per day."

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (HF-rTMS) over the left versus right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) on cognitive improvement in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: Left DLPFC stimulation significantly improved global cognition, orientation, and language, while right DLPFC stimulation enhanced visual and spatial perception. Both groups showed increased MBI scores, but no significant difference was found between them.
population_specificity: 40 patients with post-stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI).
effective_dosage: 20Hz rTMS for 20 minutes per session, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how baseline semantic and phonological characteristics of word-retrieval impairments influence the efficacy of rTMS combined with language treatment for long-term naming improvements in chronic aphasia.
results_summary: rTMS combined with modified constraint-induced language treatment (mCILT) improved long-term naming more than language therapy alone, with greater baseline semantic and phonological characteristics associated with increased rTMS-induced gains. These improvements were maintained at 3 and 6 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals with post-stroke chronic aphasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rTMS, including stimulation parameters and target sites, on post-stroke lower limb motor impairment and balance to identify clinically applicable settings.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS applied to the unaffected motor cortex significantly improved gait speed in stroke patients. High-frequency rTMS, 1000-1500 pulses per session, and ≥10 total sessions were particularly effective in enhancing lower limb balance and gait post-stroke.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients with lower limb motor impairment.
study_duration: Total session count ≥10 (specific duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal treatment duration (2-week vs. 4-week) of rTMS for cognitive improvement in Alzheimer's disease patients and identify key neural circuits associated with treatment response.
results_summary: The 4-week rTMS treatment significantly improved cognitive function more than the 2-week course, with changes in the default mode network, visual network, and motor network linked to cognitive gains. Baseline functional connectivity in these regions predicted treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Cognitively impaired patients (likely Alzheimer's disease, based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining speech rehabilitation training with rTMS improves speech function in patients with post-stroke aphasia compared to speech rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining rTMS with speech rehabilitation significantly improved speech function, cognitive assessments, and daily living abilities in patients with post-stroke aphasia compared to speech rehabilitation alone. The combined treatment group showed higher effectiveness and better scores across multiple evaluation metrics.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke aphasia (n=96).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the characteristics of rTMS treatment protocols for improving cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease patients and identify which cognitive domains are affected.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in global cognitive function but no significant effects on verbal memory, processing speed, or executive function. Subgroup analyses and meta-regression did not yield significant results.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and tolerability of accelerated intermittent theta burst stimulation (aiTBS) targeting the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (lDLPFC) for chronic knee osteoarthritis pain.
results_summary: The study found aiTBS to be safe and well-tolerated, with pain relief observed immediately after treatment and lasting 16 weeks, but no significant differences between active and sham groups. Overall acceptance and satisfaction were high (89%).
population_specificity: Patients with mild-moderate chronic knee osteoarthritis pain.
effective_dosage: 9000 pulses daily (5 sessions of 1800 pulses) for 4 consecutive days (total 36,000 pulses).
study_duration: 4 days of intervention with follow-up lasting 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neurobiological mechanisms of rTMS's antidepressant effects, specifically its impact on brain structure and neurotransmitter systems in depressed patients.
results_summary: Active rTMS showed greater improvement in depressive symptoms compared to sham, with increased grey matter volume in the frontal-limbic network, correlated with D1 receptor distribution. The findings suggest rTMS enhances structural plasticity and modulates dopamine systems for therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Thirty-six patients with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of rTMS on negative symptoms and P300 event-related potential in chronic schizophrenia.
results_summary: rTMS at 10 Hz significantly improved negative symptoms (SANS score) and P300 amplitude in chronic schizophrenia patients, while 5 Hz and 15 Hz showed no significant effects. Improvement in the 10 Hz group was influenced by patient age and disease course.
population_specificity: 105 patients with chronic schizophrenia.
effective_dosage: 5, 10, or 15 Hz rTMS, five sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rTMS improves cognitive function in stroke patients by regulating BDNF, NGF, 5-HT, and 5-HIAA levels.
results_summary: rTMS increased BDNF, NGF, 5-HT, and 5-HIAA levels, correlating with improved cognitive function (MoCA scores and n-back task response times). The changes in 5-HT and 5-HIAA levels were linked to cognitive improvements.
population_specificity: 70 patients with ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop consensus guidelines for managing concurrent substance use in patients receiving rTMS for primary psychiatric disorders.
results_summary: The expert panel provided nuanced recommendations for screening, monitoring, and risk assessment related to substance use during rTMS, highlighting seizure risk in unstable alcohol or stimulant use but noting no evidence of reduced rTMS efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with depressive, obsessive-compulsive, psychotic, or trauma-related disorders receiving rTMS.
interactions: Alcohol, cannabis, stimulants, and opioids were discussed for potential risks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on cognitive impairment in ALS patients and its impact on caregivers' burden.
results_summary: rTMS showed short-term positive effects on cognitive function in ALS patients and reduced caregivers' burden, but no improvement was observed in ALS severity or plasma biomarkers.
population_specificity: 90 ALS patients with cognitive impairment, with 80 randomly assigned to treatment or sham groups.
effective_dosage: 10 Hz rTMS applied to bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortices (DLPFC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of rTMS in smoking cessation and explore the underlying neural mechanisms of its treatment effect.
results_summary: rTMS significantly decreased cerebral blood flow in the DLPFC, reduced nicotine dependence and smoking urge scores, and increased functional connectivity between the left DLPFC and other brain regions. The study suggests rTMS may reduce nicotine dependence by modulating CBF and functional connectivity in specific brain pathways.
population_specificity: 60 participants who smoked cigarettes and 60 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 10 Hz frequency with 2000 pulses per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy of high-frequency deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) for improving negative symptoms in schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that active dTMS significantly improved negative symptoms compared to sham treatment, as measured by the Scale for Assessment of Negative Symptoms and the negative subscale of the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale. The improvements were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia experiencing negative symptoms.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of high-frequency dTMS at 10 Hz, 100% of resting motor threshold, using an H7 coil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) as an add-on therapy for fibromyalgia in women refractory to best available treatment.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS significantly reduced pain intensity by ≥50% at week 8 compared to sham, with a 99.4% probability of efficacy. While analgesic effects diminished by week 16, functional improvements persisted.
population_specificity: Women aged ≥18 years with fibromyalgia refractory to best available treatment, from Brazil, France, and Japan.
effective_dosage: 10 Hz motor cortex (M1) rTMS, 3000 pulses per day.
study_duration: 10 induction sessions over 2 weeks, followed by weekly maintenance (6 weeks), and fortnightly extended maintenance (8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) could improve learning and memory abilities and reduce oxidative stress in rats with vascular cognitive impairment (VCI).
results_summary: Low-frequency rTMS improved learning and memory abilities in VCI rats, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, Bax, Cas-3), increased neurotrophic factors (BDNF, GDNF, NMDAR1), and enhanced hippocampal synaptic plasticity (PSP amplitude) compared to the model group.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats with induced vascular cognitive impairment (VCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of rTMS in treating chronic pelvic pain syndrome and determine the most effective stimulation protocol.
results_summary: All eight studies reviewed showed a notable reduction in pain scores post-treatment, indicating rTMS is effective for chronic pelvic pain. However, variability in stimulation protocols prevented conclusive determination of optimal parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms of high-frequency transcranial magnetic stimulation on cerebral functional connectivity in patients with poststroke attentional dysfunction.
results_summary: The study will compare high-frequency transcranial magnetic stimulation with sham stimulation to assess its efficacy on attentional functioning after stroke, using quantitative electroencephalography and other secondary outcome measures. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 120 stroke patients with attentional dysfunction.
effective_dosage: High-frequency transcranial magnetic stimulation, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and feasibility of accelerated TMS (aTMS) protocols for faster treatment response in OCD compared to standard TMS or placebo.
results_summary: aTMS significantly reduced OCD and depressive symptoms and increased response rates compared to sham, though adverse effects were higher (albeit mild). Sustained reductions were seen in depressive symptoms at follow-up, but not in OCD or anxiety symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (accelerated protocols implied multiple sessions per day).
study_duration: Not specified (implied shorter than standard 6-8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, tolerability, and short-term efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) targeting the precuneus in individuals with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study anticipates that rTMS is feasible and tolerable, with potential evidence of target engagement and clinical improvement, though efficacy results are preliminary and exploratory.
population_specificity: 54 participants with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's Clinical Syndrome.
effective_dosage: 16 rTMS sessions over 5 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how coil orientation affects the TMS stimulation threshold for neuronal activation and identify optimal orientations for various current pulses.
results_summary: The study found that coil orientation significantly impacts the TMS stimulation threshold, with certain orientations minimizing the threshold for different current pulses. These findings were validated using external data, suggesting the model's potential for optimizing TMS treatments.
population_specificity: Simulations focused on the left primary motor cortical area using an anatomically realistic brain model and a representative layer 5 pyramidal neuron.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of cerebellar repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) and cerebellar Theta Burst Stimulation (TBS) in treating Essential Tremor (ET).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant difference between rTMS and sham groups for Fahn-Tolosa-Marin (FTM) subscores or total scores. Adverse events were minimal, with headaches and dizziness reported in a small number of participants.
population_specificity: Patients with Essential Tremor (ET) (261 participants: 149 received rTMS, 112 were controls).

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate whether the BDNF Val66Met polymorphism influences clinical response to a standard course of rTMS therapy for treatment-resistant depression.
results_summary: rTMS significantly reduced depressive symptoms, but no differences in response or remission rates were found between BDNF polymorphism types. The study concluded that BDNF polymorphism status may not affect the response to standard rTMS treatment for major depressive disorder.
population_specificity: 75 patients with treatment-resistant depression

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining rTMS with bilateral arm training (BAT) enhances effective brain connectivity in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS-BAT therapy led to significant task-related alterations in brain connectivity, particularly in the ipsilesional supplementary motor area and occipital lobe, suggesting a synergistic effect on cortical reorganization in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=15) and healthy controls (n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between pre-treatment systemic inflammatory markers and the response to rTMS in patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: The study found that higher pre-treatment inflammatory markers (NLR, PLR, SII) were associated with poorer response to rTMS, with NLR being a significant predictor. Early improvement in MADRS scores during the first week also predicted better overall treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: 86 patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) who received rTMS at Gazi University.
effective_dosage: 10 Hz rTMS to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (study period was June 2017 to June 2023).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the predictive capability of clinical response to TMS treatment in MDD subjects using cognitive variables and a novel brain-inspired computing paradigm (HDC).
results_summary: HDC achieved an AUC of 0.82 in predicting clinical responses to TMS, outperforming SVM by 0.07. Feature selection improved classification performance, with ws_MedRT showing distinguishable distribution between responders and non-responders.
population_specificity: 22 subjects with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in post-stroke motor impairment and explore its neural mechanisms, particularly how impairment severity influences treatment outcomes.
results_summary: TMS improved motor function in mild/moderate impairment cases but showed limited efficacy in severe cases. EEG data indicated TMS promotes recovery by modulating alpha activity and enhancing network efficiency, with FMA improvement correlating with local alpha power changes.
population_specificity: Fifty-five stroke patients with upper limb motor deficits, stratified into mild/moderate (FMA ≥30) and severe (FMA <30) impairment subgroups.
effective_dosage: Two weeks of intermittent theta-burst stimulation (iTBS) (specific frequency/duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-frequency rTMS over the left M1 differentially influences offset analgesia in the forearm (stimulated region) versus the trigeminal region.
results_summary: Active rTMS significantly enhanced offset analgesia in the forearm during the late phase but had no significant effect in the trigeminal region, suggesting region-specific modulation of central pain mechanisms.
population_specificity: 22 healthy volunteers
study_duration: Three experimental sessions (baseline, active rTMS, sham rTMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining rTMS with non-pharmacological methods (e.g., exercise, psychotherapy) enhances its antidepressant efficacy compared to rTMS alone.
results_summary: The study found large therapeutic effects when rTMS was combined with non-pharmacological methods in uncontrolled pretest-posttest comparisons, medium effects compared to sham rTMS plus active non-pharmacological methods, and no significant difference compared to active rTMS plus sham psychological methods.
population_specificity: Neuropsychiatric patients with depressive symptoms

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of eye tracking as a biomarker for cognitive changes in Parkinson's syndrome patients treated with deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) and compare it to traditional neuropsychological tests.
results_summary: The study found moderate correlations between eye-tracking parameters (e.g., longest fixation duration) and cognitive scores (MoCA), as well as a significant reduction in depressive symptoms (BDI scores) post-dTMS. However, no significant differences were observed in eye movement parameters pre- and post-treatment.
population_specificity: 10 Parkinson syndrome patients
effective_dosage: Motor cortex (1 Hz) and prefrontal cortex (10 Hz) stimulation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of low-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on treatment-resistant OCD patients by targeting the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC).
results_summary: The study proposed a protocol for applying 1 Hz rTMS to the right dlPFC, but efficacy results were not yet available as the abstract describes a planned study rather than completed findings. Previous systematic reviews indicated mixed Y-BOCS outcomes due to methodological variations.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe OCD and limited response to previous treatments.
effective_dosage: 1 Hz stimulation, totaling 2000 pulses per session, with three 40-second inter-train intervals, administered 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether 1-Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) combined with multimodality aphasia therapy (M-MAT) improves speech recovery in chronic poststroke aphasia compared to sham stimulation plus M-MAT.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS combined with M-MAT led to greater improvements in aphasia severity (measured by WAB-AQ scores) at 15 weeks compared to sham stimulation, with significant reductions in word-finding difficulties and improved sentence production. Intensive M-MAT alone also improved speech, but rTMS provided supplemental benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic nonfluent aphasia (>6 months post-stroke) due to left middle cerebral artery stroke.
effective_dosage: 1-Hz rTMS (exact number of sessions not specified) paired with 35 hours of M-MAT over 10 days.
study_duration: 10 days (intervention), with follow-up at 3 and 15 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical responses of non-fluent and semantic PPA variants to repetitive TMS over the left IFG and DLPC.
results_summary: IFG stimulation improved words per minute and subjective assessment in non-fluent PPA but had no effect in semantic PPA. DLPC stimulation improved words per minute, repetition, and naming latency in non-fluent PPA, and naming and subjective impression in semantic PPA.
population_specificity: 20 patients with primary progressive aphasia (14 non-fluent, 6 semantic variants).

study_goal: To analyze the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in treating dysarthria in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Six out of seven studies indicated that rTMS improved dysarthria in PD patients, suggesting a positive effect, though further research is needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease experiencing dysarthria.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on frequency, duration, and stimulation site).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the safety and effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in treating motor dysfunction in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that 1 Hz rTMS over the contralesional primary motor cortex (M1) significantly improved motor function and activities of daily living (ADLs) in stroke patients during the early stage (<1 month) and recovery period (1-6 months), but evidence was insufficient for the chronic phase (>6 months).
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (2951 participants across 70 studies).
effective_dosage: 1 Hz rTMS (other frequencies like 3, 5, 10, and 20 Hz were mentioned but not sufficiently evaluated).
study_duration: Varied by study, but early stage (<1 month), recovery period (1-6 months), and chronic phase (>6 months) were analyzed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on sleep quality in patients with more than mild depressive mood.
results_summary: rTMS significantly improved sleep quality in patients with more than mild depression, with better outcomes observed at 1-Hz stimulation frequency, treatment durations exceeding 4 weeks, and when used without combination therapy. Subgroup analyses identified combination treatment as a main source of heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with more than mild depressive mood.
study_duration: Varied (2 weeks, 4 weeks, and more than 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gender or age impacts the induced electric field strength and focality in the brain during Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) treatment.
results_summary: The study found patterns in induced electric field strength and focality when MRI-derived head models were divided by age and gender, suggesting these factors influence TMS efficacy. Anatomical variations in head models were also considered, further exploring their impact on field strength and focality.
population_specificity: MRI-derived head models categorized by age and gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and effectiveness of theta-burst stimulation (TBS) and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) for treating treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between rTMS and TBS in reducing depression or anxiety symptoms, nor in side effects like headaches, nausea, or fatigue. TBS was noted as more time-efficient, making it a cost-effective option for TRD patients.
population_specificity: 1,196 patients with treatment-resistant depression (553 received rTMS, 663 received TBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin C supplementation could reduce serum uric acid levels in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin C supplementation significantly reduced serum uric acid levels in hemodialysis patients after 8 weeks, compared to placebo and no-intervention control groups. No significant changes were observed in serum creatinine levels.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether ascorbate (vitamin C) enhances the antitumor effects of chemotherapy and reduces its toxicity in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found no high-quality evidence supporting ascorbate's ability to improve survival, progression-free survival, or reduce chemotherapy toxicity. Evidence for antitumor effects was limited to lower-quality studies like case reports and observational studies.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin C supplementation affects the risk of cancer events, particularly prostate cancer, in male physicians.
results_summary: The study found no effect of vitamin C supplementation on the incidence of total cancers or prostate cancer, with hazard ratios close to 1.0 and no significant interactions with other factors.
population_specificity: US male physicians aged ≥50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the time course of vitamin C accumulation in skeletal muscle and plasma during high-dose supplementation and its effects on VC transporter expression, redox measures, and mitochondrial activity.
results_summary: High-dose vitamin C supplementation significantly increased skeletal muscle and plasma VC concentrations after 7 and 1 day, respectively, and elevated SVCT2 protein expression without altering redox measures or citrate synthase activity.
population_specificity: Eight healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin C supplementation reduces oxidative stress and improves exercise performance, particularly in individuals with low baseline vitamin C levels.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with low baseline vitamin C had higher oxidative stress and lower physical performance. Vitamin C supplementation reduced oxidative stress markers (F2-isoprostanes and protein carbonyls) more significantly in the low vitamin C group and marginally improved VO2max.
population_specificity: 100 males screened, with 20 selected (10 with the lowest and 10 with the highest baseline vitamin C levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose vitamin C infusion combined with oral vitamin E could reduce infarct size in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary angioplasty after acute myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study was still ongoing at the time of publication. The primary and secondary outcomes were planned to be measured at specific time points post-angioplasty.
population_specificity: 134 adults with acute myocardial infarction requiring percutaneous coronary angioplasty.
effective_dosage: High-dose vitamin C infusion plus oral vitamin E (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of high-dose vitamin C in mitigating oxidative injury-induced microcirculatory impairment and organ failure in conditions like ischemia/reperfusion and sepsis.
results_summary: High-dose vitamin C was found to prevent or restore microcirculatory flow impairment, enhance antibacterial defense, and mitigate organ injury by reducing oxidative stress and improving vascular function. The effects were most pronounced when administered early after injury or before procedures like cardiac surgery.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients, those undergoing cardiac revascularization, organ transplant, or major gastrointestinal surgery, and preclinical models of ischemia/reperfusion or sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose vitamin C supplementation affects the plasma and blood mononuclear cell IL-6 and IL-10 response to exercise.
results_summary: Vitamin C supplementation increased plasma and blood mononuclear cell vitamin C levels but did not influence exercise-induced changes in IL-6 and IL-10 levels or oxidative stress markers. Exercise increased IL-6 and IL-10 production in blood mononuclear cells, but supplementation had no effect on these responses.
population_specificity: Participants in a 15-km run competition (n = 31, split into supplemented and placebo groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare plasma urate concentrations using two different assays in patients receiving vitamin C supplementation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in mean plasma urate concentrations between the two assays. A small, non-significant difference was observed in patients receiving vitamin C, with the non-ascorbate oxidase assay yielding slightly lower concentrations.
population_specificity: Patients receiving allopurinol and those not receiving allopurinol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of vitamin C supplementation on endothelial function and whether this effect varied by health status, study duration, dose, and route of administration.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 44 clinical trials showed a significant positive effect of vitamin C on endothelial function, particularly in atherosclerotic, diabetic, and heart failure patients. The effect size was positively associated with vitamin C dose but unaffected by study design, duration, baseline plasma vitamin C levels, or administration route.
population_specificity: Adult participants, including those with atherosclerosis, diabetes, and heart failure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (meta-regression indicated a positive association between dose and effect).
study_duration: Not specified (analysis stratified by duration but no specific duration reported).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin C and E supplementation affects endurance training adaptations, including mitochondrial biogenesis and performance metrics.
results_summary: Vitamin C and E supplementation did not improve VO2 max or running performance compared to placebo but attenuated increases in mitochondrial biogenesis markers (COX4, PGC-1α) and lowered mRNA levels of CDC42 and MAPK1 in trained muscle.
population_specificity: 54 young men and women
effective_dosage: 1000 mg vitamin C and 235 mg vitamin E daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between vitamin C supplement use and dietary vitamin C intake with breast cancer-specific mortality and total mortality in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that post-diagnosis vitamin C supplement use was associated with reduced risks of total mortality (RR 0.81) and breast cancer-specific mortality (RR 0.85). Dietary vitamin C intake (100mg/day increase) was also linked to reduced risks of total mortality (RR 0.73) and breast cancer-specific mortality (RR 0.78).
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer (17,696 cases).
effective_dosage: 100mg per day increase in dietary vitamin C intake (supplement dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antioxidant supplementation (including Vitamin C) could reduce oxidative damage and modify the antioxidant response in lead-exposed workers.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant supplementation (Vitamin C + Vitamin E) significantly reduced oxidative damage and total antioxidant capacity in lead-exposed workers, while also decreasing antioxidant enzyme activities. The results suggest that the supplementation was effective in counteracting lead-induced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Lead-exposed workers (15 participants) compared to non-lead-exposed workers (19 participants).
effective_dosage: 1g of Vitamin C daily (combined with 400 IU of Vitamin E).
